headline.main: More Faith, More Pounds, More Secure

docs.abstract: Purdue University study finds obesity to be more prevalent among religious Americans than among the nonreligious; however, the religious report higher levels of well-being than the nonreligious (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Though gluttony is cited in the Bible as a sin and a sign of moral weakness, religious people in the United States are more likely to be overweight than nonreligious people, researchers from Purdue University have found. In a state-by-state comparison, the researchers found that obesity is most prevalent in states where religious affiliation is most common, like Michigan, Mississippi and Indiana.
